>When they were at sea for long periods, all they could think of was getting back to a port where they could have a “jolly roger” with one of the local ladies

>And incidentally, what makes this one even more humorous is that around the 17th century, “to Roger” came to mean “to have sex” or “to penetrate”, from a slang for “penis” at the time. Meaning if you combine the two slang terms across centuries, he was “Penis Fuckebythenavele”

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Can we talk about Ragnarok and the future of the franchise? I was hyped for it but after finishing it I am disappointed with the story. The constant coincidences with characters appearing in just the right moments and making decisions for drama before quickly changing their mind became tiresome. Freya was ruined with inconsistent writing. She wants to kill Kratos for years, is obsessed with him, but after a single fight not even an hour passes and she is quipping jokes like in a Marvel movie. Kratos was too weak and passive, not commanding, and he was showing emotions like crying even, which I think doesn't fit him at all. The way Odin was killed was uninteresting. He was turned into a nonsensical bad guy towards the end, and he killed Thor on the spot just because lmao I am bad. Thrud and Sif added nothing of value except wasted time and Thor was poorly developed as either a villain or a broken hero despite all the time you spend as Atreus in Asgard. I think it was shallow.

The only good that came out of the story was the message that resentment is wrong and you need to overcome challenges, which is a nice change from the woke pandering that is typical nowadays.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Finally after having Diablo 4 beta access since it was announced i decided to download this 80gb monster and try it out.

And i gotta say ... expected more.

Not that i wanted it to be Lost ark, but this 1997 Diablo 2 design just feels dated. Running around and spamming the same 2 spells over and over, farming the same few mobs, might has been fun 2 decades ago when games wre simple but today feels like its lacking in player engagement, once you dump those 30 ability points and min max your build you dont have much more left to do in that regard.
I played both Diablo 2 and 3 and even Lost Ark and Path of Exile, Grim Dawn and others, but Diablo 4 seems most simple of them all. The bigger world map really adds nothing to it outside no loading screens, and with stats gone, potion management gone and no real social elements even Diablo Immortal has more going on in the meta game. Other players due to insane size of the map arent even a thing, running past another player every time you visit a city really impacts gameplay in no way.

How dated it feels hit me especially after playing Diablo 2 resurected at the same time, its literally the same game only bit more polished.
If anything Diablo 2 seems more complicated, since with enemies scaling to your level no matter where you go you are going right way, and with the new respawning world events i spend 20 minutes doing the same "save 2 people trapped under wagons" thing and it dropped me yellow items scaled to my level each time.
I dont know, i expected next generation of diablo, what i got was diablo 2 remake + open world. Visuals look ok but technically dated with non interactive environment, and the microsoft sam audio cracks me up.

Cant be only one letdown with the beta?

threads.com: Are QTEs considered gameplay or are they just interactive cutscenes?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>618259450
That is not a quick time event. A QTE implies that if you fail to hit the right button in time that you suffer.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>618259450
I wouldn't even call that interactive

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>618259450
I'd say it's not a Quick Time Event because it's not quick but, most likely, it's not even time limited so it's just a Event. It's as passing text on a VN

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
They've always been a compromise for flashier animations. From day 1 in Dragon's Lair they were introduced to simplify the game down to a set of pass or fail animations. It was a limitation of the technology that could only jump to different points of the video stream on the disc. In modern games it's used as a way to show those cinematic movie like choreographed fight scenes you'd see in blockbuster action films. They look really cool and flashy but you can't do animations and camera work like that without throwing the normal controls out the window and locking everything to heavily choreographed script.
Personally I feel like they're very much a lazy cop-out in games today. If you can't figure out how to write the screen play to go along with the gameplay then you shouldn't be writing for video games. It looks cool in trailers sure, but it's going to look a lot less cool if the player doesn't decide to press the button.
